ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Good introduction to chemistry labs.
Basic laboratory safety, how to apply conceptual class ideas to real life, and understand how to interpret data.

I have learned how to apply the material that I learned in lecture and see these concepts put to work in the laboratory. Through the lab lectures, I was able to gain a solid understanding of the various techniques needed to carry out experiments, including titration and taking measurements.
Basic lab work in chemistry
This course allowed for further development of good laboratory practices and procedures and introduced students well to Yale's lab system.
Applying skills I learned in lecture to a physical lab.

I learned a variety of lab techniques and how to apply them to the topics I was learning in the classroom. It was rewarding to see the fruits of the experimental work and learn new skills each week. I also feel like I developed a respect for sanitary technique and how this pays off in the end even when it seems tedious in the moment. Finally, I learned how to abide by professional standards for writing reports and how to convey my results more directly.
I learned how to use a few new pieces of lab equipment
I learned a lot about chemistry in general with the basic principles and theories that we supported in our experiments. Also, the importance of wearing appropriate lab-wear.

This course gave me hands on experience to content that I was learning in CHEM161. I also learned how to create a proper lab report through trial and error in this class. I also learned how and when to engage in independent and group work.
Basic laboratory knowledge
How to check significant figures and make trend-lines on Excel.
I learned lab procedures, the importance of keeping an organized lab notebook, and how to critically think and apply chemistry concepts.
Gives chem students the opportunity to see chemistry that our textbooks talk about in real life
Learned foundational laboratory skills and techniques such as carrying out titrations and expanded knowledge of use and names of tools/equipment.
Learned how to write lab reports that were clear and concise.
I learned many lab techniques that I had not previously performed, and I also learned how to keep and maintain a lab notebook, both of which I feel will be very important in moving forward with lab.

I didn't learn very much honestly, the labs very more basic than high school AP chemistry and the class took a lot of time but was busywork. The prelectures take a long time and the quizes was nice to have two attempts, but allows people to have a very high average grade. This is a curved class so the average is very high and may be curved down, which I don't think should be allowed. I think if this class was .75 credits it would be fair for the lengthy lab reports and time spent working and then having one quiz attempt so that it demonstrates students level of ability would make the class better.

I learned how to perform specific experiments and different techniques used in the lab. The experiments helped me practice a variety of useful lab skills and solidify chemical concepts. I also learned proper lab attire and etiquette.

I learned a lot about chem lab procedures and how to write lab reports.  I also felt that the experiments we conducted helped strengthen my knowledge of the topics being covered in the lecture course.
I learned a lot of laboratory techniques and how to best collect data.
I have never taken a lab course like this before so everything that we learned was new to me.
I developed basic lab skills and learned the principles of chemistry in a more hands-on setting than my lecture provided.
I learned how to use lab equipment, which is a skill I did not have before coming to Yale. The course also aided in my knowledge of chemistry topics.
Learned how to use lab equipment
basic lab skills. How to use Google Sheets to organize data.
I learned about different types of experiments and how to be efficient in lab.
I learned basic lab skills.

I learned how to use certain lab equipment, and how to carry out an experiment with a certain degree of precision. The labs were often times not very difficult, but required attention to detail, and for procedures to be carried out very methodically. Lab reports helped me learn how to present my work professionally, but were very complicated.
I learned about the standards in a lab, like being neat and wearing pants, and conducting experiments. I got to see chemistry in action. I gained skills about working with others.
I learned how to conduct myself in a laboratory setting, as this was my first experience.
I learned the basic principles and skills needed in a chemistry lab such as spectroscopy, measuring density, and simple reactions.

I did not gain much from this course. I am sure if I was worse at chemistry, I would have gotten some base understanding of a sparse set of topics, but such is not the case. Just as well, if I were better at chemistry, I may have been able to enrich my learning of concepts, especially in the later labs, but the course turns into a lot of discussion about lab-only activities that don't enhance how I understand chemistry outside of the course. The Teaching Fellows were quite helpful in explaining basic ideas as we needed them for the lab reports, but at some points, and I believe most students I have spoken to feel this, it became a matter of not understanding what to say, asking one's TF, and then altering and writing down information based on that alone. It is not dishonest, as the reflection questions encourage this cooperation and the rest of the report must be done independently, but in terms of broad concepts, it did not feel like this space was conducive to learning much of anything.
I learned to be thorough with my lab work.
learned about good lab techniques and aided in the materials from chem 163
I've gained my first lab experience after taking this course. Not a lot of the information I learned was retained, as the labs were not interconnected and focused on a new aspect every time.
Understand the purpose of an experiment and each step rather than just knowing what you are supposed to do.
Mainly how to use basic lab equipment and how to write a lab report.

Skill and practice in a chemistry lab:
How to be properly dressed, handle equipment, and general lab safety/lab course norms.
This course allowed me to create a good foundation if I were to major in Chemistry. It also made me really consider chem as a possible field of study.
Basic experimental techniques.
Basic lab knowledge/equipment, better understanding of chemistry

This course helps you become familiar with a lot of equipment and basic procedures that are used in the lab. The lab reports forced you to think about the implications of the conducted experiments and understand the chemistry behind them.
Writing lab reports was a skill that I learned during this course.
General chemistry lab skills, titrations
I learned the importance of reporting credible data, and also how to interpret it. Moreover, I learned how to use a photo spectrometer and improved my Microsoft excel skills.

I learned how to:
- Work safely in a lab
-Use lab equipment
-Correctly identify lab equipment
-perform titrations 
-use a spectrometer
-use a fume hood
-dilute solutions
-clean lab equipment
-write lab reports
-reflect on methods used in lab
-collect and store data in an efficient way
I learned how to conduct myself in the lab and to keep a lab notebook.
I learned various lab techniques including how to write lab reports and how to conduct experiments safely and appropriately.

I did learn the basics of writing and formatting a lab report while also freshening up my Microsoft Office skills with Word and Excel. What I value most that I gained was the lab experience even though it was just in an educational environment and not a research environment.
I gained an intro into laboratory procedures and practices.
I learned how to write a lab report that was up to standards, and be precise with my skills in the lab.
A variety of applications of chemistry topics learned in the classroom.
I learned basic lab procedures and how to write lab reports.

In lab this semester, I learned how to be precise. Whereas in other classes some carelessness here and there is okay, that is not the case in lab. So I quickly adjusted and started checking even the smallest details of my work. The lab reports were incredibly tedious and the grading was so picky. And in terms of being in lab, it is very hit or miss, based on your random instructor. I loved my TF, so I enjoyed being in lab.
Probably learned some lab skills, like how to use and clean burets and bulb pipets. Also learned that the (aq) in chemical equations is supposed to be in subscript.
I did not develop any skills that are necessary to facilitate my success as a healthcare professional.
I learned how to properly write a methods section and make connections between the concepts I am exploring and the data I collected.
I learned how to craft graphs on excel from data collected from labs. I also learned how to write lab reports and different materials around the lab.
Outside of conducting experiments, one of the greatest insights I developed was writing a lab report.
I knew most of the lab techniques used prior to entering the course, but had forgotten specifics especially with titrations.

Mainly lab report-writing skills - writing clear/concise aims, how to graph and interpret data, how to think critically about results
Also some lab methods/skills such as titrations, reading a spectrometer, how to use LoggerPro, how to use a lab notebook effectively
How to think critically about creating experiments, the strengths and weaknesses of experiments, and developing a better understanding of the chemistry learned in lecture.

I learned some basic lab skills (like titration and electrolysis) and how to write an effective lab report. I found that taking this course in conjunction with CHEM 161 helped me solidify my knowledge, since we were tested on the calculations that we learned how to do in lab!
Applied gen chem topics to hands on labs. Received some guidance on how to compose a well structured lab report.
how easy it is for an experiment to go wrong; how important it is to maintain lab safety; how to use different lab equipment
I learned how to work in a lab and became familiar with lab equipment and procedures.
Learned a lot about the introduction to research and laboratory techniques in chemistry.
I learned various lab techniques and how to use quantitative lab data to demonstrate chemistry concepts.

I improved my ability to carry out experimental procedures in a chemistry laboratory. I also honed my lab report writing skills and solidified my grasp on concepts that I encountered in general chemistry lecture.
I learned a lot about the scientific process and how precise you need to be in data gathering and processing.
I learned lab skills and how to translate my chemistry knowledge to actual experiments.
Basic lab techniques and experiments such as spectrometry and titrations; learned how to use LoggerPro and produce formal lab reports
I learned how to work in a lab environment, which was really fun since I've never been in a full lab like this.
I learned about lab safety and a bit about some chemistry lab procedures.
I think that I learned more about lab equipment and saftey.
I was able to gain basic laboratory skills, learned how to follow a lab manual, write lab reports and present data.
I learned about the value of precise and caution in the laboratory as well as the importance of keeping organized, detailed notes prior to and throughout an experiment.
How to write a lab report among other basic lab techniques.

I gained essential research skills that will assist me in future research and lab work. Those skills included proper usage of lab apparatus, navigating applications such as LoggerPro, and writing quality lab reports. The course applied general chemistry concepts in experiments which allowed me to understand those concepts better.
Basic skills in a chemistry lab and how to relay those experiment results onto analysis.

Through this course I developed a deeper understanding of chemistry and how to conduct myself in a lab. There were many opportunities to become acquainted with various lab materials that I had not previously encountered. The lab manuals and videos detailed the experiments with enough clarity to make the lab feel constructive. One of the major points of growth I experienced in the class is understanding how to write a lab report and make sure there is consistency and attention to detail throughout. This course gave insight into many of the foundations of lab work that cultivates a strong foundation for continuing lab experiences outside of the classroom.
I got more comfortable in the lab
The basics of the laboratory and how to work with chemicals in the lab.
Chemistry laboratory practices
I learned laboratory techniques that included titrations and explorations of gas laws, among other Chemistry concepts.
I learned how to write a lab paper and analyze data and create graphs
Basic Chemistry Lab skills and how to use different instruments. How to write a very basic chemistry lab report.
I learned about several experimental methods and how to compose a proper lab report.
I learned how to use various lab equipment and document data in a lab notebook. I was able to actually see the science behind concepts I learned in chemistry lecture.

The lab gave me basic insights into chemistry. We learned various science topics ranging from mass and density to intermolecular forces. The class taught me the basic chemistry. It was a nice review from AP Chemistry in high school because we covered topics like gas laws and did basic calculations.
In the lab, we worked on improving lab skills such as accuracy and precision. We also familiarized ourselves with the lab equipment.
Basic laboratory skills and foundations of chemistry.
I learned how to perform many lab techniques like acid base titrations and run the LoggerPro program. It overall helped me build foundations to become a better scientist.
How to take  chemistry lab notes, writing lab reports, learning new chemical techniques
I sharpened my careful measuring skills, and improved my precision at scientific lab work. I also increased my speed and efficiency at such projects.
Taking this course allowed me to gain hands on experience with chemistry. Conducting experiments on the same topics we were learning in Gen Chem 161 deepened my understanding.
General lab skills.
Chemistry laboratory skills (titrations, weighing, gas/calorimetry equipment) and applying knowledge from the gen chem course.

I got a refresher of the names of different types of lab equipment and learned how different lab procedures work as well. I also learned how to write up a proper lab report which is something I had no prior experience in.

Through this course, I developed laboratory skills such as being able to use all of the equipment, and being able to perform simple experiments. I also gained some general chemistry knowledge as well.

I acquired basic laboratory skills as well as the ability to report and analyze laboratory work in a clear and concise fashion. 
Through these activities, I also acquired more insights into certain chemical processes which facilitated understanding in chem 161.
I developed lab skills, critical thinking, following procedures, and practical understanding of chemistry concepts.
I gained critical thinking skills and was able to supplement by learning of general chemistry through development of laboratory techniques. I also learned how to use lab tools.
Use of tools in laboratory setting, how to write thorough lab reports.
I learned about the basic lab techniques and experiment that went hand in hand with Chem 161
I learned how to write a proper lab report, collect/interpret scientific data, and carry out basic laboratory tasks.
I learned the various basics of chemistry lab, such as titration and using scales. I learned how to write a concise lab report.
How to conduct chemistry in a laboratory setting effecitvely.

I developed my scientific thinking and laboratory skills in this lab course. Before this class, I had never stepped foot into a lab environment or used any of the materials in it. I learned how to use those materials correctly.
I learned lab safety skills, how to use basic lab equipment, and how to perform important measuring and experimental skills.
Taking this course greatly improved my attention to detail when measuring or recording information, and even in calculations.
I learned how to operate in the lab.
Practice with fundamentals of chemistry, getting hands on experience.
Presentation skills

I learned what the professional standards for a lab report are.
I learned how to think more critically about data and how to apply experiments to what I am learning in class.
I learned how to use Excel in ways I havent before.
I learned how much I benefit from group work.
I learned basic lab safety procedures, how to conduct experiments in a lab, and how to apply the things we learned in chem lecture.
Students learn basic lab techniques, as well as begin to learn how to write a good lab report including procedure and presenting results.
I learned how to carefully assess all the resources I have and use them to the best of my ability.
Learned about basic chemistry lab techniques and processes; how individual processes and findings can be extrapolated to understand broader phenomena
This class encompasses basic lab procedures, lab techniques, safety, and use of laboratory instruments in order to apply principles taught from general chemistry.
I learned basic chemistry lab skills and how to use excel.
I gained an introductory understanding of how to perform experiments safely and write analysis of those experiments inside a lab setting.
I gain skills in laboratory ethic as well as comprehension of the chemistry involved in our labs.
Lots of lab skills and techniques
I really did not learn much in this lab. I just followed random procedures and mixed chemicals and just wrote down what happened. The labs really did not make much sense to me.

I learned about various different skills used in the chemical laboratory, from titrations to precipitation analysis to light spectroscopy. I learned about proper technical laboratory techniques and what makes an experimental design effective or not effective, helping me develop critical reasoning skills.
This class taught me a lot about scientific methodology and how to write a valuable lab report.

Proper PPE attire and codes of behavior were taught to us which is very useful information as first semester college students in a science lab. Furthermore, the proper lab notebook strategies as well as how to correctly and exceedingly write the lab reports for submission.
I learned how to work with others and how to prepare for lab.

This course helped me better learn the concepts of Chemistry 161 by providing me with first-hand experience of these concepts. I also learned how to deal with challenges when they occur and learned how to use lab equipment.

Through this course, I was able to review old and new chemistry topics that weren't explicitly discussed in my Chem 163 class. I learned a wide range of techniques that would serve me well in future lab classes. Additionally, my ability to work in a team was greatly improved throughout the course of this semester.
Basic lab techniques
I learned basic lab skills.
I practiced basic chemistry lab skills, and had reinforced certain topics from general chemistry.
Lab skills

This course allowed me to have a better understanding of concepts that I was learning in CHEM 161. Through this course, I was able to understand real world applications for the topics that we covered.
Learned to follow lab protocol, use lab equipment, collect data, conduct experiments, and write lab reports.

I learned all the ins and outs of working in a college-level lab, I learned how to be an effective participant in a lab setting, I learned how to write a high quality and detailed lab report, and was able to apply concepts learned in chem lecture to lab, thus helping my understanding of general chemistry concepts.

- How to conduct a few chemistry experiments
- Integrating some of the equations and skills we learned from general chemistry into lab work
Learned how to carry out procedures using lab equipment. This was helpful to get a hands on approach to reinforcing what we learned in lecture.
I learnt how to write lab reports.
I learned how to carry out many basic chemistry procedures in the lab. I also learned how to apply significant figures in calculations and use them to write a lab report.
Intro to chem lab techniques, equipment, report-writing (including graphing, so much graphing familiarity gained!) and communication, and the application of theoretical content in hands-on work
I learned how to use various tools in the chemistry laboratory and how to write detailed lab reports.
Learned "Lab etiquette" and how to know what to expect, lab time management.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think this course was set up well. The TFs were extremely helpful and there were always resources available to succeed.
Labs were quite engaging and the reflection questions on the reports allow for collaboration,  TA's are super helpful and available, and Dr. Parr is really great at explaining things!

This course was very well taught through the lab lectures and provided enough information to understand what the procedure was when it came time to carry out the experiment. In addition, I really liked how a lab manual was provided for each lab, which explained the appropriate steps we should take when carrying out each experiment. I would say the weakness in this course would be the low number of supplies available. There would be times where I felt that time was wasted in lab waiting for other classmates in my section to use the supplies needed. I think it would be more effective if each student/pair of students were provided with their own set of materials to carry out the experiments.

Strengths - clear in-lab instructions and manuals / pre-lab videos
Weaknesses - rubrics for labs were sometimes unclear

The course is a strong introduction to the laboratory procedures at Yale and affords students the chance to get comfortable with lab equipment through relatively simple procedures and calculations. However, my biggest qualms with this course are in regards to grading. Having raised a handful of grading issues throughout the semester with incomplete responses, I find myself frustrated that the grades I received were not comparable to classmates who submitted similar lab reports. Quiz grading is generous as are policies around re-opening assignments (Dr. Parr was beyond amenable here in re-opening closed assignments for students throughout the semester). I also think that this course is great for those taking CHEM 161, however, it does not line up at all with the curriculum for CHEM 163 and I don't think it added to my learning in that course at all. Perhaps a CHEM 163 specific lab section within the Gen Chem Lab umbrella would be more beneficial.
Good class, I learned a lot. A lot of work and course is only worth 0.5 credits.

This course provides a strong foundation in lab work and features a wide array of experiments. You get to solidify your techniques and apply them to new experiences over the course of the semester. The pre-lab lectures and lab manuals are informative and often provide supplementary information to the topics at hand. The report-writing sessions at the end of the term were very helpful and took some of the stress off of the reports. 

In terms of the weaknesses, the expectations of the first lab report were unclear. The course provided resources on writing reports afterwards, but they should have been available when all of us were writing our first reports. Also, this course and the chem lecture course were sometimes out of sync, so the lab expected us to know information we hadn't been taught yet. Finally, I wish the grading distributions were clearer because it made writing the reports unnecessarily stressful. Since the averages of the reports were generally high, it made you feel like if you messed up the slightest detail, it could move you down a grade level. Some more clarity about the grading scheme and overall expectations could have redressed some of these fears.

I can honestly say that I understand next to none of the chemistry that we actually did in lab. The lab reports were often very confusing, and I was unable to answer the questions without considerable help from my TF. Very little was explained to us well, and if I was asked now to explain why we did any of the things we did, I would be unable to.

A weakness was that I had never done a college lab report before and this course jumped in with the assumption that I knew how. With that being said, a strength of this course was that I felt like there were enough resources to reach out to for help. I also felt like for a course worth 0.5 credits, I did the same amount (if not more) work than I did for my higher weighted classes.

I did like that this course helped my to apply concepts I learned in lecture. I'm a very kinetic learner, and being able to see and touch the concepts being described was very helpful for me. I do wish there had been more instruction on how to write a lab report - perhaps an example document or instructional video. Simply having to learn from scratch after the first lab report was disheartening. Otherwise, I felt that it was arranged very nicely to facilitate learning. The curve is a little harsh - if they don't want so many students to get an A, they should alter the content or assessment methods, not make it so that getting an A requires a raw score of 98+.

The labs are really interesting to do, but the grading is just so harsh on the lab reports that it takes away significantly from the overall quality of the class. They're not difficult, just extremely tedious. I would finish most of them in an hour or two, but then need to spend 5 going over again and again, because your grade goes down significantly for missing a single digit. I highly recommend going to office hours frequently, since the reflection questions are always vague but are looking for very specific answers. The TAs will tell you what these are, but theres almost no way of knowing on your own.

One strength of this class is its collaborative nature. I enjoyed working with lab partners and lab TFs to gain a deeper understanding of the chemistry concepts involved in our experiments. This class requires some time and effort, but there is a lot of support to help you through.
weakness: too much work, strength: my TA was great

Strengths: great foundation for chemistry lab. Also, the grading was fair since it was a different TF grading every lab report so it minimized bias. Weaknesses: wish it was a full credit class instead of a 0.5 credit class.

Strengths: TFs were always willing to answer questions. The labs themselves were not difficult. 
Weaknesses: Points were taken off on lab reports for very minor things.

I believe the course was fairly straight forward. There were many hours offered for receiving help and the assistance was helpful as we navigated our lab reports. However, I sometimes felt like certain TFs could be a little condescending, which did not help my confidence in the lab setting. Additionally, there was also a pretty significant disparity in the grading of lab reports-- occasionally I would get points off for the same answer my peers got full credit for, so maybe there needs to be a better standard enforced for reports.

It can be improved by having more advanced experiments, the level of chemistry was incredibly basic, and also one quiz attempt. I also found as a Monday lab, the lab reports could sometimes have questions phrased confusingly and the office hours weren't scheduled to help us. As an athlete I have practice right after lab finishes so can't attend the Monday session and the lab is due that night. There weren't office hours over the weekend and during the week right after lab, I went to sessions but there were many students all asking for help on the previous lab due that night who were given priority so it was a waste of time and made it more difficult when working on the lab reports to have access to help as easily as other days.

One strength was that each lab section was assigned a TF so they could help if needed during the experiments. Enough information and resources were provided to complete the lab reports. I also liked that we had pre-lab lecture videos to explain the lab, but they were sometimes extensively long with a lot of background information. The course could be improved by shortening the length of the pre-lab lecture videos or splitting them up.

All in all, I liked this course a lot.  The one downside was that I felt that the workload was too much for a half-credit course.  If it had been a full credit, I would have felt better about the amount of work.  But Dr. Parr was amazing and made the time in lab feel very fun and productive.

I really think that the way lab reports are graded is not helpful to students. The grading is so particular and picky, that this class was more about focusing on tiny formatting details than the content itself.

One strength is that the TAs and instructor were all very helpful if we didn't understand a concept. A weakness is that my chemistry class with Dr. G was not in synch with the lab, and we were learning the concepts from the lab in class like a week or two after I already did the lab.

I liked how the course was split into lab sections as such that it was possible to learn from my peers. I also liked how the prelab videos were informative and told us everything that we needed to know for the lab.
I liked how we got to see the lab done in the prelab video. I think it would be more beneficial to see more calculations regarding the lab.

Strengths: you do hands-on chemistry. Weaknesses: difficult to navigate if you've never taken a lab class. If you have Monday lab its difficult to get help in office hours. The experiments are difficult and the lab reports take a long time to complete with not very much guidance if you've never written a lab report before. The course claims its for beginners but its really not.

Strengths: We had some very cool lab experiments and you learned improve time management skills immensly. 

Weaknesses: There was a much greater workload than advertised. the lab reports were graded differently depending on which TA graded them. The labs often took more time to complete than other classes that were a full credit while lab is only a half credit.
It's a solid intro lab course. Nothing is too challenging and the pre-lab videos explained everything needed for that week.

I felt that the experiments we were carrying out didn't really explain in the lab why we were focused on the things we were recording, and then the lab reports asked us to draw conclusions based on our data and use our data in complex, sometimes unfamiliar calculations that were not very intuitive. I would leave lab feeling pretty assured that I knew what was going on, and then when I started the report I had a million questions. I also feel like the rubric punished little mistakes, so I was worried about little technicalities on my report rather than just demonstrating that I understood the takeaways of the experiment. Some strengths were that there were a wide range of experiments, so at least now I feel pretty confident in a lab setting going forward.

It required full participation which was engaging and I had fun. The experiments could be challenging but were always doable and they always made sense. A weakness is how Sometimes there would be multiple labs on the same day, which had little to do with each other, that was kind of confusing. Also, there was little assistance when doing lab reports. A lot of times the TFs with office hours were not the same people grading the lab reports so they didnt know how to help.

The time commitment was high when you account for the videos, lab reports, quizzes, and time spent in lab, and I feel that it is deserving of a full credit. A strength is that the TFs were extremely helpful in making the labs easier to understand.
weakness: only 0.5 credits even though the work load is comparable to all of my 1.0 credit classes. Also, the curve means that you can have a 95% and still end up with an A- or B+.

This course makes students stress out so much about the curve, and I believe that type of stress made me care more about checking off all of the boxes into making the lab reports correct and pretty than actually learning the material. That sort of high stress environment, with gossip about who the "harsh-grading TFs are," and high averages which indicate ridiculously steep curves, really disenchanted me with my hopes for learning in the lab, making me leave MCDB as my intended major. I believe there is a serious issue with the intensity of the grading curve and how that impacts the learning environment. If that would be remedied, I think I might have enjoyed learning a bit more.
I think it should be a 1 credit course.
well structured but took a lot of time

The access to teaching fellows was predominantly restricted to be over zoom, rather than having in-person office hours as well. However, nearing the end of the course, in-person hours were implemented, making finishing assignments much easier. Also, I soon found that having a Monday lab was a disadvantage as new lab lectures were usually not posted until Sunday, making a thorough understanding of the lab a bit difficult to reach.
This course was well organized, but labs were not always graded and returned in time for people in the Monday section to receive feedback before they had to turn in the next lab report.
I felt like the labs improved my understanding of lecture material.

Some strengths of this course included the small group-type nature of the class where a TF oversaw a group of around 10-12 students and aided in lab work. Weaknesses may include the amount of unnecessary work the course provided.
The course was very detailed but given in a form thats easy to understand.

Strengths - good for learning how to do experiments. 
Weakness - grading (from what I have heard)
The work is definitely enough that it should be a full credit. Also, the grading/expectations for lab reports werent made very clear

The labs often don't take up the full four hours, but the lab reports can take time and be difficult. There are resources available to get them done and TFs were very helpful. During the labs, TFs are always there to help you out. The pre and post-lab quizzes can be confusing and difficult to figure out sometimes.

A strength was the availability of the TFs and their willingness to help. A weakness was the lack of work for lab partners. I think that collaboration with a lab partner would have helped me learn more and actually discuss what we were doing it instead of just following out a set of instructions.

Strengths: TFs (depending on who you get) are dedicated to teaching, Dr. Lant will help you. Weaknesses: Dr. Parr's video lectures were at times unclear, the lack of direction in lab, especially for Gen Chem I, is mildly concerning.

Strengths- Have access to all the TFs and the daily discussion sections that help a lot with completing lab reports. 
Weaknesses- Students are not taught how to plan an experiment.

Even though this is an introductory course, it is taught with little aid for those who have never had lab experience. There is a lot of figuring things out on your own especially on the lab reports. There were many times I stayed up for long hour just trying to figure out how to complete a certain graph despite being an active participant in the experiments. The quizzes are geared towards those in Chem 161. Chem163 students did not have the same education before hand to accurately answer the quiz questions without outside research/learning the content. The pre-lab videos could be much more interactive and less lengthy.

The experiments performed were pretty great. I believe they are essential when starting lab work. The lab environment was very inviting.
The course is interesting overall, but the pre-lab lectures are a hassle since they add a lot of time to the already very long class time the course takes up plus the time to complete its workload.

The prelab videos were too long and not useful. The lab content usually didn't match up with what we were doing in 161 so I spent a lot of time really confused about the content. My TF was super sweet and lab was really well organized. There was a good support network.

Strengths: learned a lot of new information that is helpful in working in a lab (expectations for attire and note-taking)
Weaknesses: pre-lab lectures were often very long and lab report grading was slightly unhelpful for future labs. THE NEGATIVE CURVE IS TERRIBLE!! Expect to work hard, but if you are at average your final grade might not reflect your true numeric value.
The rubric in grading can be a little clearer, and it seems like there is too much discrepancy in grading the labs, as it is very common for students to get points off on something and others to not

strengths: 
- engaging and attentive experiments
weakness
- not much guidance outside of the classtime for lab reports

A strength is that there are a lot of TAs to answer your questions. However, the weaknesses far outweigh the strengths. First of all, I found myself doing a credit's worth of work for the half credit class. For example, I spent just as much time (if not MORE if I wanted to get a good grade) preparing for this class as I did with chem lecture. Second, I disliked that the labs were graded very harshly and that it is basically required of you to contact the TAs for lab regrading in order to succeed in this class when it was never mentioned to the students (personally found this irritating to find out as a first-gen student). Third, I disliked how the class is said to be "curved down" which makes this such a competitive course to take and overall it did not foster a sense of collaboration as I would've like to have seen especially with the sheer amount of pre-meds taking CHEM 134L.

All the TFs were so helpful and friendly  they were always so patient with our many questions. I liked when there were office hours. That prevented us from wasting time on a lab report question that could quickly be resolved. 

I wish there were more explanations about how the lab relates to what we learned in chemistry class WHILE in the lab, instead of just making the connections when working on the lab reports. Everyone always dreaded the lab reports. They were unnecessarily nitpicky and took so long to complete - if you didnt want points to be taken off for small details.

Weaknesses: consistency in grading. For example, one TA literally used a different set of rules for sig figs than I learned in Chem 161 or literally in any other class I have ever taken (or any webpage I have visited in my life). When I inquired about this, I was told that there were two different "schools of thought" for the sig fig rule for addition/subtraction. Also, in general, some graders graded much more harshly than others.
Another weakness: ambiguity in what we were expected to do for lab reports. I would ask my TA whether I should do a specific thing on a graph (like connect the dots between adjacent data points or include all 10 sig figs provided by logger pro) and they would say, "maybe, I don't know, up to you" or something like that, but I wasn't sure whether I would be docked points for choosing one way or another, and I would ask Dr. Parr and still not totally be sure, because it might seem to conflict slightly with what my TA said, or with what Dr. Parr had previously said in a pre-recorded lecture video, or with what the written instructions said, or what my friend's TA had said, etc.
Also, I was extremely worried about grades throughout the whole course, because the syllabus said that the B/B+ cutoff would be the course average grade, yet the average grades for the lab reports was consistently very high. So even though I was scoring really high scores, and I was above the average for most/all assignments, I wasn't sure if it would be enough to get an A once the curve was taken into account. It seems like this sort of class, where almost all students consistently score really high scores, is a terrible candidate for a curved grading system, because it would make people with high grades, like a 95% in the class (indicating high proficiency in relevant skills/understanding from an absolute point of view), still get a mediocre final letter grade because everyone else in the class also happened to do well from an absolute point of view.
I think that this course could be improved by increasing the credit given. It doesn't make sense to be taking a course as stressful as this and to only be given .5 credits.

The class is difficult for students who have no previous lab experience because we are expected to come in knowing how to use certain materials, which can be problematic because if we havent used them before, it will be harder to collect proper data.
Sometimes, the video was a bit lengthy and I wish Dr. Parr could be a bit more concise.

strength: the labs were cool, especially the spectrometer and electrolysis lab. TFs were extremely helpful! I recommend going to their office hours. The structure was also good. I liked doing the prelab work online before going into the lab and then doing the post-lab work afterward. That allowed us to just focus on completing the lab and allowed us to leave early on most days. I also liked the study hall sessions we had since they helped me finish the lab reports on time.
weakness: grading scale. It sucks that people who had an A the entire semester grade would deflate to a B+.

A strength for the course was the professor himself; Parr was exceptional during lecture, really engaging. 
A weakness would be the specificity of the lab reports. At times I felt as it the grading was a bit harsh.
the graders were not always consistent

Strengths: well organized, lab manuals were comprehensive, TAs and Dr. Parr receptive to emails for help

Weaknesses: if you have Monday lab, sometimes the lab manuals/lectures aren't posted until late the night before, often the material hasn't been covered in chem161 lecture yet, and most difficult/stressful, there are little to no TA office hours available (if you go the week before, as I've done, the TA's don't have the rubrics etc yet so they can't help, and the one office hours that was on Monday was booked a month ahead of time- I emailed weeks out and could never get a meeting). So oftentimes my friends in later labs would meet with many TAs and get help on the entirety of their lab while I could not, which is stressful when the class is graded on a curve.

The course is half a credit but you spend hours in lab and outside of lab working on your lab reports. If it had been one credit it would have made sense because overall I really enjoyed this class and found it interesting to see how we could approach research in a new way,

Strengths: Fun labs, engaging pre-lab lectures
Weaknesses: Not sure this can be changed, but I really don't understand why this is half a credit. It was more work than any of my full credit courses. Also, I thought that for the Friday lab, the 24hr window for post-lab quizzes was a bit unreasonable. People have intense extracurriculars over the weekend and on Friday night. 48 hours would make much more sense for the lab section that completes the quizzes over the weekend.
The guidance on the reports was weak. Office hours were often full and I could not get off the waitlist. Often felt lost on calculations, wish there was more guidance.

very clear and organized. pre-lab videos were quite long. walking through the calculations in these videos was super helpful - used as an example when having to do my own. 

maybe there could be a stronger connection between the lab and CHEM 161? I get that this only makes sense if everyone takes both concurrently. 

strength: communication and support. 

could add a regular office hours to help with lab reports, the way it was done for the last two reports.
Strengths include challenging students in a way that they leave lab with greater insight and knowledge about how to function in a lab setting.
The time requirement and difficulty was as expected, and the TAs were helpful in assisting. There can be room for improvement in terms of describing what is needed in the lab reports.

The prelab lectures provided a clear understanding of what would take place in lab that week, and the labs themselves were generally interesting and insightful. A weakness is that sometimes the time commitment for the lab and the lab report were too much.

strengths: Prelab Videos were extremely helpful; Teaching assistants and Dr. Parr, overall, were extremely helpful and supportive throughout the experimental execution and lab report writing processes; Experiments were sometimes time-consuming but doable with the help of the manual, prelab videos, and teaching assistants/ Dr. Parr

weakness: High workload felt tedious at times. For example, I understood the purpose of the pre lab quizzes, but the postlab quizzes felt a little redundant considering that we already had to write lab reports anyway.

The experiments were fun and everything was organized but there was a lot of work and some of the grading was very variable from ta to ta. A little more consistency in what they were looking for would be nice.
Strengths were definitely Dr. Parr and the TFs, which made lab super enjoyable and something to look forward to every week. Weaknesses are probably the harshness of grading.

Towards the end of the semester, the TFs started providing in-person office hour sessions in the Chemistry building to help with the lab reports. Those sessions were incredibly helpful and effective. I just wish that they'd been offered from the start of the semester. Definitely go to as many TF sessions as you can because that's how you'll best understand what they're looking for when they grade your lab reports. Be prepared to spend a lot of time on lab reports because they make up the bulk of your grade and you need to score consistently well.

Another thing to note is that final grades are determined in the context of the class average, with students who score a little above the average getting a B+ and students who score a little below getting a B. So if you have an A when the class ends but the class average is also an A, your grade won't necessarily stay an A when final grades are released. I enjoyed the class and the lab experience, but that aspect of it was frustrating and unfair. If you put in the work and earn an A, then I think it should stay an A.

The time in the lab was mostly used well - it was an engaging space, and it was in lab that I learned the most in this course. My biggest suggestion involves the lab reports - the rubrics for the reports resulted in a grading system that was harsh and arbitrary. I spent much more time repeatedly going over my lab reports checking for small requirements related to format and presentation than I did actually engaging with the content, and I would not have continued with the course were it not a requirement for my major.
I think that a strength is the experiments. Most of the experiments were fun to complete. A weakness is that there appears to be a grading difference with TF's.

The course is overall very well-designed with the detailed pre-recorded lectures, pre- and post-lab quizzes, and lab write-ups. There is plenty of opportunity to receive support during lab. The lab reports really enable you to develop your scientific communication skills.

The strength of this course is hands-on learning and engagement, however, the weakness is the amount of work that comes with the course. For half a credit, this course carried a lot more work than expected -- almost as many hours per week as my full one-credit STEM courses. Another weakness may be that expectations for lab reports were never fully reviewed. Despite this, in the grading process, these expectations were upheld and greatly impacted one's grade repeatedly throughout the semester for myself and my peers. Also, grading of the lab reports greatly depended on who was grading them -- the different graders appeared to have varying expectations -- which made it very difficult to learn from past errors and improve to get a better grade when expectations depended on the grader.
The lab reports seemed at times excessively detailed

Extremely confusing curve. Everyone gets an A and small differences in your grade as a percentage end up deciding entire letter differences. Also extremely unequal grading of lab reports from different TAs and extremely vague rubrics for said lab reports

I felt that the grading rubric for the lab reports did not reflect student knowledge of the material. I found that the rubrics were looking for very specific answers to questions, without giving consideration to the quality/depth of knowledge of student answers.

The lab reports were very long and often seemed arbitrary compared to the material. Also students in chem 163 were extremely disadvantaged because 134L is aligned to 161 but in 163 we learned completely different material. Like when we did a gas law lab we were doing organic chemistry and I hadnt studied gas laws in at least a year. Additionally the workload was too high for the credits of the class. I understand that labs cant be a full credit like other classes but the time commitment was equal to or more that my 1 credit or even my 1.5 credit class. I think the workload should be diminished either with less lab reports and experiments and/or more time to complete them. Towards the end of the semester we had some time during the lab block to work on the reports with the TAs which I found very helpful, but at the beginning I was spending ~3 hours in lab which is the same as my other classes and then spending 5+ hours on the reports.

One strength of this course is the detailed information students receive prior to experiments. The detailed lectures and manuals ensure that we understand what to do for labs and conduct them without too much difficulty. Another strength is the large amount of help offered. There are many office hours available to attend and the instructor, preceptor, and teaching fellows are always willing to answer questions through email. I found lab reports easy to navigate because it was easy for me to get clarification on parts I was confused about.
Strengths were comprehensive prelab information and knowledgable TFs. However, at times the prelab lectures could become tedious.

One of the strengths of this course is the detail of the lab work that allows for a greater understanding of the concepts being learned in the accompanying chemistry course. The lab also helped understand the visual and hands on aspect of  the chemistry concepts that are not able to be seen in a book. One of the weakness of the lab is the learning curve of the reports that is not fully explained in the rubric. Since there are very disparate experiences of students within lab there should be more support initially rather than gradually throughout the course. The outside lab work is comparable to a full credit course; however, since the lab is only a half credit there was a considerable amount of time dedicated to the lab that seems disproportionate.

The only weakness of this course is the way it is graded. I've just learned that the class average, nearly 97%, will serve as the cutoff between a B and a B+. This seems absurd to me. In what other context would obtaining 97% of possible points not be considered the highest of achievements? If the professor wants to grade on a curve, he must allow for more differentiation in scores throughout the semester.
Strengths are the organization of the course the weakness is the lack of communication regarding final grades.

The strengths of this course are the Teaching Fellows who made themselves available for help during the experiments and after the fact as well. The weaknesses of this course are that it requires heavy focus and attention, superseding the amount of credits it is worth. The lab report grading rubrics were also very specific and tedious.
The strengths were how I developed a better understanding of a lab environment but the weaknesses were how much time it took out of my day and the amount of time I generally spent on this subject
This course is a great introduction to working in a lab setting. Its biggest weakness is the amount of credits it's worth. I ended up putting more work into it than some of my full credit classes.
This course was very easy to follow, but some of the lab report specifics were difficult to get help on.

The strengths was the pre lab lectures as the demonstrations were very helpful when actually doing the lab in person. A weakness would be the grading, especially since some TAs were more nitpicky than others which would make it uneven.

One strength is that the pre-lab videos were very helpful and included everything we needed to know about performing the lab. The TFs were also always open to answering questions and there were plenty of office hours to attend. One weakness of this course was that it was sometimes a lot more work than I would expect a half credit to be. I think this could be improved by shortening some of the pre-lab videos or having reports due the day after your lab so you aren't working on finishing a report and doing pre-lab assignments at the same time.
The labs are, in general, quite easy to follow, and the lab reports are straightforward. I liked that multiple labs were sometimes included in one lab reportthis made the workload more manageable.

While I understand the idea behind curving the course, I found that people who had labs on different days of the week might experience differences/advantages to having their lab on a later day (i.e. when asking TFs about questions, they appeared to be more knowledgeable later in the week). Thus, having the course curved to encompass all lab section members felt at times skewed. I also received different opinions from different TFs when asking a question, which I found confusing.

Strengths of this class was definitely how well organized the course was. The pre lab lectures were easy to follow and the manuals guided us through all of the experiment. The TAs did a wonderful job at introducing every lab and helping with the actual lab. A weakness would be sometimes the lab manuals had different instructions than what we were given from the TA.
This course helped with understanding general chemistry concepts and actually working with chemistry. However, lab could be disorganized at times, which led to some confusion.
Its quite a lot of work for a half credit class, however, the experiments were very well-designed and engaging. They tied to the Chem 161 lectures nicely.
Strengths: taught basic chemical lab skills and how to write professional lab reports. Weaknesses: workload was very high for a half-credit class.

One strength of this course is that it gives you a very good understanding of how lab work should be conducted. There is also a lot of guidance from the Teaching Fellows, which is very helpful.

One weakness of this course is that, in a few of the labs, the quantities of reagents were so stringent that they left little room for error. So on a couple of occasions, students who made a small mistake had to start from scratch since they needed to make more of the reagents. Given that most of us have not had training in such precision previously, it would be better if the class took that into consideration, and made us produce reagents in excess to account for error.
Another weakness was that, although we received guidance on small details in the lab report, it was really hard to gauge how long they wanted the introduction/background/objectives section. It seemed that they were stringent about length while simultaneously asking for a degree of detail that would make the report longer anyway. It would be nice if there was clear guidance about the level of detail required (e.g. an example).

Strengths - good choice of lab experiments and are quite organized.

Weaknesses - can't work with group, TAs are inconsistent with instruction, high marks for lab reports are awarded on arbitrary details.
The pre-lab lectures were extremely helpful as well as the labs where we were able to work in partners. It was nice to have someone you can bounce ideas off of.

One strength of this course is the number of resources available to answer and questions or clarify any points that are unclear. All of the labs are completed in the presence of a teaching fellow, who is able to answer most questions.

A strength of this course is that it is well organized and leads students through a progression of ideas and skills.
A drawback to this course is that the workload does not align with the number of credits. I personally spent at least twice as much time on this course than I did my general chemistry course, but this was worth half the credit.
The workload was heavy for the amount of credit received for the class

I appreciated that my lab TA helped me explain the structure of the lab before we actually started -- in addition to the instructor's prelab videos. I also loved that there were tutoring sessions in case you had questions about your lab report.

This course could be improved by more standardization among TFs when it comes to grading band amount of help given. There seemed to be major inconsistencies between how harshly lab reports were graded. Some TFs provided much more help upfront on lab reports than others.

Strength: was Professor Parr and the TAs, very attentive and helpful
Weakness: More feedback on Lab Reports

The online pre-lab lectures were sometimes unclear. Furthermore, when we arrived in the lab it was assumed that we already had a preliminary understanding of how to use some of the laboratory equipment. As someone who came into uni with absolutely zero chem lab background, this was very frustrating and discouraging at times.
The TFs were all very helpful and provided a lot of support. Sometimes the guidelines for the lab reports were unclear and confusing.
It could be confusing at times as well as a lot of work but it also was very informative and helped gain an understanding of hands on chemistry.

A strength of this course is that students are able to engage with the lab in an immersive way. The course is designed for students with no prior experience and the experiments are easy to follow. A weakness is that the lab reports are sometimes difficult to complete because lab moved faster than gen chem content.

The pre lab lectures were very helpful and all of the professors and TFs were always happy to answer any questions during or after lab. A weakness was the lab rubrics. Sometimes it was hard to understand what was expected for certain parts of the report.
I think the instructions should have been more detailed on lab report assignments.

The people with earlier lab days felt at a disadvantage as compared to people with later lab days since a lot of the time the TF's wouldn't have the rubrics by the time the earlier lab days lab reports were due. This made it so that when they went to office hours for help the TF's couldn't always help them, whereas people with later lab days never ran into this problem.
I liked the structure of the course, and appreciated the available support with writing lab reports.
I think the metric system is better
The grade deflation in this class is concerning.

Strengths: Having a TA who can help you with the lab
Being able to ask classmates questions

Weaknesses: The grading system. Even though there were rules out in place to protect against bias, some of the TAs were harsher graders than others, so two people with virtually the same lab report would have different grades. 
Some of the lab report templates had words I didnt understand because of the discrepancy between British English and American English, which wouldnt be a problem if words were defined beforehand.
A lot of the pre-lab lectures were entirely too long. I understand that theyre helpful in completing the lab reports because they go through examples, but it adds to the workload and I often went into lab without watching the lecture because I didnt have the time beforehand.
The course gave students enough time to complete lab reports and provided lots of help if needed.

The course felt like a bit of a waste of time. Four hour lab sessions are long and most people, including the TFs really dont want to be there, which makes it feel even longer. The prefab lectures were long and disorganized and would be much more effective as shorter videos coupled with readings.
Strengths include the style of the pre lectures and quizzes and a weakness would be the grading system.

I enjoyed how hands-on this course was; it was always interesting to come to lab and learn about different techniques. However, I felt as if the workload for this class was excessive for its credit. Even though 134L is a 0.5 credit course, I ended up working on it more than almost any other class. Lab reports seemed to have arbitrary grading standards at times and required a significant amount of time to calculate and completeoften due to redundancy and the need to type out calculation. For almost every lab, I noticed that there were "hidden points:" criteria which weren't explicitly stated in any rubric or instruction set, but upon asking my TF, were critical to the lab, and without which, I would have lost points. These points were confusing, and oftentimes, I found myself revising a lab report right before the due date because I just became aware of some other component or explanation that the labs required. Clarifying the grading criteria for each lab report would be very helpful and, honestly, make the course accessible for those new to STEM fields.

That clarity is also useful considering the near-obscene curve the class is graded with. The B/B+ average for the class was a 97.5%. In any other discipline or class, a 97.5% is rewarded and understood to constitute near-perfect understanding of the material. For 134L, however, a 95-97% was a B, and I'd imagine that a grade highly regarded in another discipline, such as a 94%, would be punished. To grade the class on a curve where an A would be nearly a 99% only harms students, rather than aiding their learning. To curve students down and to set the bar at nearly 100% is illogical and harmful. Personally, I don't see the need for a curve in 134La student's grade should reflect a student's performance, and a grade range skewed upward does not. There's almost 0 margin for error in this class, far beyond the point at which error reflects lack of understanding.

Strengths: well-organized, routine schedule, different experiments each week helped spark some interest, very helpful TFs.
Weaknesses: Lab reports are graded along a very strict rubric (losing points for very small errors), which makes lab reflection and learning not enjoyable. Additionally, sometimes lab procedures are very long.
The syllabus was a little off from the actual course. Same thing applies for lab manuals. I really liked the fact that quizzes gave you two tries. I also liked how lowest scores were dropped.

The teaching fellows were excellent. Dr. Parr's pre-lab videos and clear instruction overall were extremely informative, and I loved that the course was very structured and easy to follow, with clear expectations. The only way I could think of improving this course is increasing number of office hours as I was sometimes not able to attend the times at which they were held.
More in-depth feedback on how our labs can be improved would be helpful.
I really wish there were better explanations as to what was going on in the lab. The lab pre videos were too long and not that helpful. Many of the basic chemicals and procedures were foreign to me.

Strengths of this course included the depth and breadth of different chemical techniques explored in all the labs, which really allowed me to explore how diverse and rich the world of chemistry research really is. The pre-lab videos and manuals were really great resources that helped me thoroughly familiarize myself with the lab techniques I should expect before the lab. The post-lab quizzes helped me test my knowledge of the subject further. I also was pleased with the fact that the topic for each week's lab corresponded with the content of general chemistry course, keeping me engaged with the subject and allowing me to tangibly apply what I learned from the textbook in real life.

A weakness of this course was that because so many different TFs were grading our lab reports, it was sometimes tricky to know what to expect in terms of how the lab would be graded. However, there were additional resources created later in the course to help mitigate any confusion regarding formatting and other lab report logistics.
A weakness is the delay in lab report grade release, which could have helped when writing future lab reports. Additionally, this course should count as a full credit rather than half of a credit

This course was very well planned out and organized. The division of two tables per teaching fellow facilitated a very close and efficient lab environment. The teaching fellows were always available to help at any moment, either in lab or over email. One way to improve the course is being less strict with the lab report scores, and maybe keeping the same people grading the students every time to reduce differences in scores every time.
The tf's were very helpful but I wish they had more entire group study halls.

The strengths of this course were that it had pre and post lab quizzes online with two attempts. This allowed me to really understand the topics before I went into the lab because I was able to correct and learn from my mistakes. Because my lab was on Monday, it was difficult to attend office hours concerning the lab that was due because the office hours during the week were dedicated to the lab that had already been due for me. This could be improved by having more office hours available on the weekend.

I believe the lab workshops that were sometimes held were a strength of this course. They allowed me to meet new students in the class and provided immense help. The TFs were very willing to answer questions, so they helped clear up any confusion I had. I believe that one thing that could be improved is more standard grading practices. Some TFs were more lenient in grading the lab reports than others, it seemed like. It would be better if we had more justification for the grades that we received.
The grading between TAs seemed fairly inconsistent. The labs felt interesting and relevant.
more interaction with professor

One strength of this course is that the preparation for the labs, in the form of pre-lab lectures, are very thorough. They provide a nice overview for the concepts of the lab. One thing that would make the lab quizzes more beneficial is if they do not reveal the correct answers if a student got it wrong on the first attempt. I think a system where a small percentage of points was deducted for a wrong attempt would encourage students to keep trying and revising their solutions instead of just giving them the answer after they get it wrong.
I feel that I had a great TA so the course was very manageable. We were guided through every step and the structure of the course was clear. My only complaint is the grading scale is very harsh.

This course is a great introduction to a lab setting that is fairly forgiving, the prelab lectures are clear and make conducting the actual lab much more straightforward, the experiments are interesting, the TFs are very helpful, and the chemistry concepts covered in lab compliment those covered in chem lecture nicely. The two weaknesses of this course are how the grading on lab reports can be quite harsh at times as well as how it's unclear whether or not you're allowed to print out the lab procedure and bring it to lab with you.

Strengths:
A few of the TA's were amazing!!! I've listed three phenomenal TA's at the bottom - all three were so great I feel that I have to mention them here.
Dr. Parr's video lectures were also helpful
Weaknesses:
The online, graded quizzes weren't difficult but very annoying... small mistakes on the quizzes can be devastating, especially with the curve... I think the quizzes were helpful with comprehension but they shouldn't be graded.
Lab reports made sense but the grading on them is incredibly difficult when the curve is factored in... Every week, I spent hours upon hours writing my lab report, consulting TA's, and checking my lab reports for typos and still would sometimes lose points for tiny errors

However, my biggest recommendation would be to make the quizzes ungraded... I understood the purpose and appreciated the review, but it created a lot of unnecessary stress.

Strength: clear procedures provided
Weaknesses: unclear rubric/instructions on how to start lab reports initially

There were many weaknesses of this course. The workload was extremely large for a half credit class and the curve was incredibly steep making it almost impossible to get an A without devoting 12+ hours to this course weekly.

A strenght of this course is that it teachces many important laboratory skills and also provides students with a lot of support as they are learning how to carry out these procedures. A weakness is that the procedures outlined in the prelab lecture and guide sometimes did not match the procedure we were told to carry out in class, however this was very infrequent and not of great concern because the TFs always guided us through any changes.

Strengths: good guides from instructor before labs, clear lab manuals, amazing TF Improvements: need much more clarity on the expectations for the lab reports and to please post the rubrics sooner for people taking lab earlier in the week (earlier due dates for their lab reports). Also, PLEASE make this course worth more than 0.5 credits due to the work that was needed to complete the lab reports!
This course was a great opportunity to conduct experiments and follow procedures in a laboratory setting.

Strengths: A lot of guidance for lab procedure
Weaknesses: 
I had Monday Lab and there was not much guidance for the Lab reports(i.e sometimes rubrics weren't posted until 7 hours before it was due).
Lab reports grading was very arbitrary depending on the grader.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to those who is interested in an introductory lab course.

It is a prereq for a lot of classes so yes I would. It definitely is not near as horrific as everyone says that it is. It was actually a lot of fun and was probably one of my favorite classes this semester and was a great introduction to lab at Yale. But, I would only say take it if you have to. You will learn a lot and do far more work than what a half credit class deserves to assign and curve makes it the grading pretty tough.
Yes, it is very useful to observe and further understand the concepts that are covered in the chemistry lecture course.
Yes, it was fine. Usually required if you're in gen chem lecture already

Most students taking this course don't choose to, it's required for their major or pre-med requirements. That said, if you are choosing to take this course, I'd only consider doing so if you are in CHEM 161. If you're in CHEM 163, the content does not line up at all with the lectures or material and makes for a distraction to greater Chemistry learning. It does provide a strong understanding of laboratory procedures.
Yes, if they are looking to go into any chemistry or pre-med field.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It provides a great foundation for lab work if you continue in the sciences. While for many of us in the lab it was initially just another prerequisite, I'm happy to say that it became so much more than that by the end of the semester. Spending time in lab was a really fun part of my week, and I'm excited for my future labs.

No. I do not think that I learned anything about chemistry from this class, and I don't think my experiences will be very helpful in the future. The amount of work given is much greater than it should be for a .5 credit course.
Yes! I thought it was a very good introduction to laboratory work with an emphasis in growing rather than getting it correct.

I would recommend this course if you think you are interested in chemistry. I had a change in heart on my prospective major because while I enjoyed what I was learning, I found out that it was not what I wanted to pursue as a career. This course offered clarity to what I wanted to pursue during my time at Yale.

I doubt many people would be taking this unless they had to, but out of all of my required STEM prerecs, this has been one of my favorites. The workload is high for half a credit, but as someone that learns by doing, taking this lab really enriched my understanding of the content in 161.

You probably have to take it if you're in this course. The labs are often fun, the lab reports are pretty bad. But I wouldn't worry too much, it's more tedious than difficult. Just make sure to go over lab reports a million times and go to office hours, and you should be fine.
Yes, I very much enjoyed this class. I would recommend that anyone who takes chemistry should also enroll in lab, as it provides a place to actively engage in the chemical concepts we learn in class.
only take this class if you are required to
Would recommend only if it is part of their major requirement.
Not a bad course, but I would only take it if it's required for premed or your major.
Yes, if they need it.
It's required for many majors so many people have to take it. Some friends like science labs but aren't science majors and wouldn't recommend since it is a lot of time on dull material.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It was a good introduction to performing experiments in chemistry and demonstrated chemistry concepts in a real-life lab scenario. We learned many useful techniques in lab to perform different chemical experiments. Also, the hands-on approach helped reinforce chemistry concepts.
Yes!  If you're considering this course, it's probably because you have to take it to fulfill a requirement, but don't worry - you'll enjoy it anyway.
I wouldn't recommend it unless you have to take it for premed or your major.
Yes because you can learn new skills and if you take it with the chemistry class you can connect them and learn from them both.
Yes. It's a great way to get some lab experience, especially if (like me) you haven't worked in a laboratory setting before.
Yes, this course is a great supplement to General Chemistry and also very interesting.
I would say to take this course only if they need to for requirements/premed.
I would only recommend this course to a person that has to take it as a Lab requirement.
no, I would not recommend this class unless you need it for pre-med which was pretty much everyone in the lab.
Only if it is required for a major or the pre med track.
Yes, if you need a chem lab credit. Otherwise, it's a decent basic lab class.
I would only recommend this course to students who have a chem lab requirement.
Yes If you like science and are willing to devote a chunk of time in your day bonding with other people about chemistry.
I would recommend this course if it is required for a STEM field, but otherwise I would look for another STEM class.
Yes, if you want a very basic introduction to a chemistry lab

This course, by design, is necessary for a lot of STEM majors. It must be recommended to those people, but I can only begrudgingly say that, as I found it work-intense and stressful. On top of that, since it is only worth 0.5 credits, it will not help out anyone who does not take another 0.5 lab in terms of providing a Science distributional credit, so really, I recommend people, perhaps, put it off until they get through gen chem and then stagger the labs if such is a possibility. If one does not go beyond introductory chemistry, this course will not be of any help at all.
yea - its a fine class but just a lot of time will be spent on the lab reports
I would not. This course is worth too much time and yields too little credits.
Yes, if you are committed to chemistry.
I would not recommend it if a student is not required to take it. If they are, I would say it is an okay class due to the large workload.
Yes, if it is required.
This courses is very useful for those looking to major in chem or a chem related field.
Yes.
If a prerequisite yes. If not then no
Yes, if you are interested in chemistry. It helps you become familiar with a lot of equipment in the lab.
If they needed to take it yes, but it is too much work to take if not a prereq.
You probably have to take this course anyways.
Yes! There is a lot of opportunities to work in groups/pairs and so it is a great way to meet and make friends. Moreover, you learn essential lab protocol.
Yes, I would recommend this course. It is a great way to have an introduction to laboratory work.

I think for a general lab, this lab did a great job at being informative and engaging. The lab lectures before lab were very clear at what we need to do, and the procedures were not immensely confusing. The lab reports were also very clear and effective.
I would recommend only if they need it as a prereq

I would only recommend the course if they are a STEM-interested student and have not taken another type of lab course. Otherwise, I would not recommend the course because of the large time commitment.
Yes, but only if it's in addition to or after Chem 161/163 and you want a good introduction to what labs are like (or if you're looking to get into research).
Yes, for sure! If you're pre-med, I would say this class is very useful. Dr. Parr could sometimes be a little intimidating and very strict in the lab, you learn by being under pressure.

Yes, if one were to take chemistry 161 I strongly believe that this course well accompanies the lecture and helps with the understanding of chemistry concepts.
